SUSPENSION OF MEMBER
(Speaker's Ruling)


    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the ruling of the Speaker admitting the motion of the Deputy Prime Minister in regard to the Member for Hong Lim be rescinded and that this Assembly has no jurisdiction to deal with the matters raised therein.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, before I proceed with the subject of my motion, I wish to draw your attention to today's Straits Times which contains an account of today's proceedings. Page 1 of today's Straits Times contains a paragraph which reads as follows:

    `This right has been admitted in the case of the House of Commons and in all Legislatures patterned after it.'

There is another paragraph at page 20 which reads:

    `Last Monday, the Speaker ruled that under Standing Orders the Assembly had powers to discuss the motion and, if the evidence warranted it, to find the member guilty of "dishonourable conduct".'.

Mr Speaker, Sir, it reads on:

    `He also said that the Assembly had inherent powers, should a member be found guilty, to suspend or even expel him.'

Column: 812

Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to seek your opinion as to whether any of the passages referred to is a matter which is sub-judice.

    Mr Speaker: The answer to the question is that there is no matter which can be considered sub-judice at the moment. The expression "sub-judice" is used with reference to a court of law. If the Member for Hong Lim is raising the point as a matter of privilege, then I will look into it and make my decision at some other time. Is that the point the Member for Hong Lim wishes to make, whether or not there has been a breach of the privileges of this House?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Yes, Mr Speaker, I wish to raise this point as a matter of privilege. I wish also to draw your attention to the fact that this report is not only contained in the Straits Times but a similar report also appears in other newspapers.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I shall look into the matter and give my ruling on some other day.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, coming back to the motion. First of all, I must ask your kind permission to permit me to trace very briefly the events in this Assembly before the motion by the Deputy Prime Minister was introduced.

    On 20th October, 1960, during the debate on Malayanisation, I was challenged in this Assembly to repeat outside the speeches I made.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I know it is a very difficult problem facing hon. Members, especially the Member for Hong Lim, but at the moment we are dealing specifically with the motion by the Member for Hong Lim which challenges the ruling of the Speaker in admitting the motion of the Deputy Prime Minister. It seems to me that the motion raises a matter of academic interest, and the arguments should be confined to arguments which are of academic interest. I do not know how the incidents which led to the motion which was filed by the Deputy Prime Minister have anything to do with the motion we are now considering.

Column: 813



    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir,I am trying to trace the events which precipitated this motion so that we can discuss whether the Deputy Prime Minister raised this motion in order to uphold the dignity of the House, or whether it has got anything to do with the practice of parliamentary democracy.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I am afraid if the hon. Member does that, he will go very, very far away from the motion itself. The motion merely asks this House to say that the ruling of the Speaker admitting the motion of the Deputy Prime Minister in regard to the Member for Hong Lim be rescinded. The House is asked to rescind that ruling and then to say that the Assembly has no jurisdiction to deal with the matters raised therein.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Would you, Sir, allow me to continue from where I left off on Monday on quotations from Sir Ivor Jennings - just short extracts?

    Mr Speaker: Yes, certainly, if they are relevant to the motion.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Sir, Ivor Jennings, one of the foremost British constitutional lawyers, has said in his book Parliament:

    `The power of the Opposition rests only on sufferance. There is nothing whatever in the constitutional machinery that prevents an Opposition from being suppressed. Nor is there anything effective to prevent the power of the Opposition from being completely destroyed by the destruction of free elections. The Opposition cannot out vote the majority. It can only carry out the threat to defy it and appeal to the people.'

    Mr Speaker, in the debate last Monday, we were assured by the Leader of the House, in his speech, that freedom of speech is not in danger. Sir, freedom of speech is the cornerstone of parliamentary democracy. We would have been happier if that were the true position in Singapore today.

    The motion by the Deputy Prime Minister has quoted a historical precedent. I have not been able to search a similar precedent in other Parliaments where a Member of the Parliament has been charged with making so-called malicious falsehoods and his suspension is asked for.

Column: 814



    Mr Speaker: Order. I have indicated before that I do not like having to intervene in a matter of such grave magnitude to the House. But it seems to me that the Member for Hong Lim is now going back to the original motion. What I think the House is interested to know is, on what grounds does the Member for Hong Lim say that the ruling of the Speaker should be rescinded and that the Assembly has no jurisdiction to deal with the matters raised in the motion of the Deputy Prime Minister? Mr Ong Eng Guan.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am coming slowly to the subject. The Leader of the House quoted 12 instances of breach of privilege, but he has not indicated which of the 12 commandments I have violated. Sir, it is my submission that this Assembly is not a sovereign Legislature. This Assembly is unlike the House of Commons. It is most important and vital to bear it in mind at all times during today's debate that this Assembly does not possess the same inherent powers as the House of Commons. Sir, this is my first submission.

    On this subject of the powers and privileges of colonial legislatures, may I be allowed to quote from Martin Wight's book The Development of the Legislative Council which I got from the Assembly Library yesterday? This is a research on the development of colonial legislatures between the years 1606 and 1945. Mr Martin Wight says on the subject of "Privileges":

    "As colonial legislatures have not the powers of the House of Commons, so they lack the House of Commons' privileges. Under the old empire, the colonial assembly regularly claimed parliamentary privileges, and governors usually conceded the exemption of assemblymen from arrest and suits at law during the session of the legislature, but as a royal grant, not an inherent right. Under the new empire, there existed means of checking colonial pretensions; and when in 1839, in the course of the troubles that led to the suspension of the first representative constitution of Newfoundland, the Newfoundland assembly ordered an arrest on a complaint of contempt of privilege committed out of doors, the case was carried to the Privy Council, which held that the assembly had only such powers as were reasonably necessary for the proper exercise of its functions as a local legislature, but not `the exclusive privileges which the ancient law of

Column: 815

England has annexed to the House of Parliament'. Subsequent judgments have confirmed that a colonial legislature can remove an obstruction to business, but not punish for any action taken. The extraordinary privileges of the British House of Commons, existing by ancient usage and prescription, are the consequence of its complex and unique origins which transcend the merely legislative function. They cannot be claimed by a colonial legislature by virtue of performing similar legislative functions, but only by virtue of its own enactment. `There is no doubt that apart from statute a colonial legislature had no more real power than a debating society except in so far as measures to preserve order therein might be allowed to take more drastic forms than in a mere debating society'.".

    Sir, that is my first submission.

    In support of this first contention, Sir, may I quote from the book by Sir Henry John May on the South African Constitution, wherein he writes on the powers and privileges of Parliament? Sir, on page 126 of his book, Sir Henry John May wrote:

    `In the United Kingdom, Parliament has from ancient times enjoyed certain privileges and powers founded mainly upon the law and custom of Parliament lex el consueludo Parliarnenti based upon ancient usage. Each House adjudges whether any breach of privilege has been committed and punishes offenders by censure or commitment the courses of which can now be inquired into by the courts of law. This body of custom, though narrowed and confirmed by statute is peculiar to the Parliament of the United Kingdom and it cannot therefore be inferred that like power belong to the legislative assemblies of comparatively recent creation in the dependencies of the Crown. When a Legislature is created in a colony and no special statutory powers are granted to it, it possesses only such powers as are reasonably necessary for the proper exercise of its functions and duties as a local legislature. The deciding line is to be found in the distinction between the powers to punish for contempt, which is the judicial power, and the power to remove any obstruction offered to the deliberations or actions of the legislative sitting, which last power is necessary for self-preservation. If a member of an assembly is guilty of disorderly conduct in the House while it is sitting, he may be removed or excluded for a time, and even expelled, so that the House may proceed with its deliberations. But there is a great difference between such powers and the judicial power of inflicting a penal sentence for the offence. The right to remove in order

Column: 816

to facilitate the business of the House is one thing; the right to inflict punishment is another.'

Mr Speaker, Sir, may I, with all humility, submit to you that this Assembly has no inherent power which the House of Commons enjoys? This House has no inherent power even if this, Sir, is a sovereign legislature. As I mentioned just now, Sir, in the South African example, the powers and privileges of Parliament have to be derived from statute. Sir Henry John May wrote in his book, which I quoted just now, on page 127:

    `It has therefore been thought necessary specially to grant the Union Parliament [i.e. the Union of South Africa Parliament] such powers and privileges as it should have. Section 57 of the South Africa Act provided that until Parliament was able to draw up its own code, the powers and privileges of the Cape Parliament were to apply [i.e. the Cape Parliament]. In 1911 Parliament [i.e. the South African Parliament] passed the Powers and Privileges of Parliament Act. This is a comprehensive statutory code defining the powers and privileges of Parliament and of its Members and Officers, and contempt of Parliament, and it regulates the methods by which contempt of Parliament may be punished.'

    Sir, arising from my submission just now, firstly, the power to condemn, and, secondly, the power to suspend Assemblymen in this House must be derived from statute. There is no inherent power as there is in the House of Commons. Therefore, it must be derived from either (1) the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958, or (2) it should be derived from an Ordinance passed by this Legislative Assembly, or (3) it should be derived from the Standing Orders of this Assembly.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I shall first speak on the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council. Apart from section 48 empowering the making of Standing Orders, the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council contains no provision which could be construed as directly creating a power in this Assembly to regulate its own internal affairs. The only other provision of this Order in Council relevant to the privileges of the Assembly is section 59, which reads:

    `It shall be lawful, by law enacted under this Order, to determine and regulate the

Column: 817

privileges, immunities and powers of the Assembly and its Members but no such privileges, immunities or powers shall exceed those of the Commons' House of Parliament in the United Kingdom or of the Members thereof.'

Mr Speaker, Sir, this is not a direct grant of privileges. It is thus clear that the Singapore Constitution does not make provision for the expulsion pf Members. It is also my submission, Sir, that the Singapore Constitution does not make provision for the suspension of Members.

    It is therefore my second submission, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the second part of the Deputy Prime Minister's motion is ultra vires the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council. 1958. Sir, we must thus seek the power, if there is any, in an Ordinance. The only relevant Ordinance is Ordinance No. 33 of 1955 - the Legislative Assembly (Powers and Privileges) Ordinance. Section 20, which is the only provision, empowers, the Assembly to suspend Members but only in the case of contempt of the Assembly. Section 20 defines "contempt of the Assembly" as:

    `(1) Any member of the Assembly who

    (a) being a member of a Committee of the Assembly, publishes to any person not being a member of such committee any evidence taken by the committee before it has been reported to the Assembly; or

    (b) assaults or obstructs a member of the Assembly within the Chamber or precincts of the Assembly; or

    (c) assaults or obstructs any officer of the Assembly while in the execution of his duty; or

    (d) is convicted of any offence under this Ordinance,

shall be guilty of contempt of this Assembly.'

Mr Speaker, Sir, the motion by the Deputy Prime Minister does not charge the Member for Hong Lim for contempt of the Assembly. I am not being charged for having violated any provisions of the Legislative Assembly (Powers and Privileges) Ordinance. Sir, it is therefore my third submission that the Singapore Legislative Assembly (Powers and Privileges) Ordinance, 1955, does not empower this Assembly to pass the second part of the Deputy Prime Minister's motion, that is, to suspend the Member

Column: 818

for Hong Lim on the charges laid down in the first part of his motion. Sir, from there onwards -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I would like, and perhaps the Members would like, to clear the issue. It seems to me that the hon. Member for Hong Lim is now debating as to whether this Assembly has he power to, suspend or even to punish, apart from the powers given by the statute. What I think the honourable Members of this Assembly would like to know, and I myself would like to know, is whether or not this Assembly is debarred from debating the Question - there is a subtle difference there. I trust the hon. Member for Hong Lim is following me. I think what the Assembly would like to know, on the motion before this Assembly, is whether or not this Assembly is even barred from debating the subject matter. As to what the Assembly can do in the circumstances is also another issue, that is the punitive power of the Assembly. Is the hon. Member for Hong Lim now alleging that this House has no jurisdiction even to debate the substance of the motion by the Deputy Prime Minister? I think that is the issue which has been raised in the hon. Member's motion. The other issue is how far the Assembly can go in the matter. They are perhaps issues which can be taken up when we deal with the Deputy Prime Minister's motion. The point now is: can this Assembly debate that motion?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will come to that later. Continuing from what I said just now, it is my third submission that since the Singapore Legislative Assembly (Powers and Privileges) Ordinance declares itself, in its long title, to be "An Ordinance to declare and define certain powers, privileges and immunities of the Legislative Assembly", and since by section 2C it does declare and define the power of suspension, it follows that no other power of suspension exists. Mr Speaker, I will come to the first part - if I could try to explain. I am trying to go through both parts in one breath.

Column: 819



    Sir, let me now refer to the Standing Orders of the Singapore Legislative Assembly. Is there any power under the Standing Orders for the Deputy Prime Minister's motion? Last Wednesday, when the Deputy Prime Minister wanted to move a motion for suspension under No. 30 (e) of the Standing Orders, it was ruled that Standing Order 30 (e) should he read in conjunction with Standing Order No. 56. Reference was therefore made to Standing Order 56, paragraph (5), which reads as follows:

    `Nothing in this Standing Order shall be taken to deprive the Assembly of the power of proceeding against any Member according to any resolution of the Assembly.'

Sir, may you permit me to dwell at some great length on the interpretation of S.O. 56 (5)?

    In the past two days, I have gone through the Standing Orders of many other colonial legislatures, and they are basically the same. They are based on model Standing Orders adopted by the Colonial Office Conference in 1927. Thus, Standing Order 56 (5) of the Singapore Standing Orders is to be found in the Standing Orders of almost every other colonial legislature. Before I dwell at great length on Standing Order 56 (5), may I first explain that paragraph (2) of Singapore Standing Order No. 103 could also be found in the Standing Orders of other colonial legislatures? Standing Order 103 (2) states that in any matter for which the Standing Orders of Singapore do not provide, the relevant practice of the House of Commons shall be followed, but no restriction which the House of Commons has introduced by Standing Order shall be deemed to extend to the Singapore Assembly or its Members until the Assembly has itself provided by Standing Order for such restriction.

    Sir, first of all, what is meant by "the relevant practice of the House of Commons" on the suspension of Members? According to Erskine May, in his authoritative work "Parliamentary Practice", (16th Edition.). pages 104 and 105, it appears that suspension can still theoretically be imposed at the discretion of the House of Commons, But on 25th July,

Column: 820

1877, as a result of persistent obstruction by Members, Mr Speaker Brand made the following ruling:-

    `The House is perfectly well aware that any Member persistently and wilfully obstructing public business without just and reasonable cause is guilty of contempt of this House and is liable to punishment, whether by censure, suspension from the service of the House, or commitment, according to the judgment of the House.'

This is reported in the House of Commons Parliamentary Debates 1877, 235, col. 1814. Therefore, in February 1880, the procedure for suspending a Member was laid down in Standing Order 22 of the British House of Commons. Please refer to page 471 of Erskine May. The House of Commons' Standing Order 22 is similar to the Singapore Standing Order 56. Since February 1880, it appears that no suspension of Members has been made except on grounds contained in Standing Order 22. It seems, therefore, that in the House of Commons, suspension of a Member has been restricted to cases covered by the House of Commons' Standing Order 22, which is Singapore Standing Order 56. Although the House of Commons, in theory, has inherent and absolute power, it nevertheless, Mr Speaker, is restricted in its practice by a huge body of conventions and precedents. This is important, and we should bear this in mind when we interpret the words "the inherent power of the House of Commons".

    Sir, this restriction of powers on the suspension of Members in the House of Commons has been introduced in Singapore by Standing Order 56. My submission to you, Sir, is that according to the practice of the House of Commons, the Deputy Prime Minister's motion is out of order. The Deputy Prime Minister has not quoted any precedent from the House of Commons' practice to back his case. Sir, suspension of a Member under Standing Order 56 must comply with the following conditions:-

    First, the offence must be (a) disregarding the authority of the Chair, and (b) persistently and wilfully obstructing the business of the Assembly by abusing the rules of the Assembly;

Column: 821



    Second, the motion must be made immediately after the commission of the offence.

Mr Speaker, Sir, I have not been charged for having violated Standing Order 56 or any other Standing Orders of this Assembly. Can this Assembly use Standing Order 56 (5) to suspend a Member? Standing Order 56 (5) cannot be interpreted to mean that this Assembly can pass any resolution for whatever reason against any Member. These are my arguments. Sir. Standing Order 56 (5) cannot be taken in its literal sense as Standing Order 30 (e) cannot be taken in its literal sense. Otherwise, acting under Standing Order 30 (e), this Assembly can suspend a Member at any time without notice, without reason, without debate, and even during his absence.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been ruled that Standing Order 30 (e) should be read in the general context of the whole Standing Orders of the Singapore Legislative Assembly and with special reference to Standing Order 56. It is thus my contention, Sir, that likewise Standing Order 56, paragraph (5) should be read in the general context of the whole Standing Orders of the Singapore Legislative Assembly with special reference to Standing Orders 52 to 58 which come under the general heading of "Rules of order in the Assembly". The whole purpose of Standing Orders 52 to 58 is to preserve order in the Assembly. Everyone of these seven Standing Orders deals with rules of order. Briefly they are:

    Standing Order 52: The Chairman to be heard in silence.

    Standing Order 53: Decision of the Chair is final.

    Standing Order 54: Irrelevance or repetition may cause speech to be discontinued.

    Standing Order 55: Disorderly conduct.

    Standing Order 56: Order in debate.

And in this Standing Order 56, a Member can be suspended only for disregarding the authority of the Chair or persistently and wilfully obstructing the business of the Assembly by abusing the rules.

Column: 822



    Standing Order 57: Suspended Members to withdraw from precincts of the Assembly.

    Standing Order 58 gives the Speaker power to adjourn or suspend a sitting in case of grave disorder.

    Sir, it is clear that these Standing Orders, that is, Standing Orders 52 to 58, are rules of order in the Assembly - that is, order in debate - and if a Member has not been guilty of any offence under any of such Standing Orders, no motion to suspend is justified under the Standing Orders, and it is, therefore, out of order.

    Mr Speaker. Sir, I have not been charged for any offence against these Standing Orders. It is therefore my contention, Sir, that Standing Order 56, paragraph (5) is controlled and restricted by Standing Order 56, paragraph (1) according to the rule of law known as usdern genesis, that is, of the same kind or nature. This is one of the rules of construction applied by the courts in construing documents of all kinds, whether statutes, deeds, mercantile documents and others. My submission is that S.O. 56 (5) is therefore restricted to those grounds of suspension set out in S.O. 56 (1) . S.O. 56 (5) should be read under the general heading of Standing Orders 52 to 58. "Rules of order in the Assembly". Under Standing Order 56 (5) , a Member, as distinct from the Chair, under S.O. 56 (1) may move a motion against another Member for having violated S.O. 56 (1) to maintain order in the debate in case the Chair did not move such a motion.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, therefore S.O. 56 (5) is very useful in case the Chair is occupied by a less capable person or by a Party man. It is also my contention that the phrase in S.O. 56 (5) "Proceeding against" cannot be interpreted to include the powers of suspension or expulsion. It could mean reprimand. It could mean that this House can levy, say, a forfeit or anything on a guilty Member. Mr Speaker, Sir, if it were ever intended that S.O. 56 (5) should be read in its literal construction, then my submission is that Standing Order 56 (5)

Column: 823

should have been a separate and independent Standing Order when the model Standing Orders were drafted and adopted by the Colonial Office Conference in 1927, and not as a paragraph under Standing Order 56. Sir, it should be as an independent Standing Order. Perhaps a new Standing Order to be numbered, say, 104, after the 103 Standing Orders in this Assembly. It should be taken out of the heading "Rules of order in the Assembly".

    Sir, in 1927, when the Colonial Office Conference was held and which adopted the set of model Standing Orders for all colonial legislatures, most of the colonial legislatures then were having official majorities with the Governor taking the Chair. The colonial legislatures were legislative only formally. For though its consent is necessary to pass legislation and the Annual Estimates, that consent is assured by the official majority. The capacity of the unofficial members, mostly nominated, is really advisory. The nominated unofficial members, being nominated by the Crown, will always co-operate with the Crown on general policy and important issues for obvious reasons. The most important activity of these Colonial legislatures at that period was the debate on the Annual Estimates. This is what Martin Wight in his book, "The Development of the Legislative Council" at page 123 said:

    "`There is no doubt that apart from statute a colonial legislature had no more real power than a debating society except in so far as measures to preserve order therein might be allowed to take more drastic forms than in a mere debating society.' ".

    Sir, I emphasise the words "to preserve order". The Singapore Standing Orders are based on the model Standing Orders of the Colonial Office Conference of 1927, and Standing Orders 52 to 58 are meant just for the preservation of order in this Assembly.

    Sir, during the past two days I have made a study of the Standing Orders of other colonial legislatures. May you permit me to reproduce here the equivalent of Standing Order 56 (5) in the Standing Orders of other legislatures to show the

Column: 824

interpretation, and they are all concerned, Mr Speaker, Sir, with breaches of order? First of all, Nigeria. Under the Standing Orders of Nigeria, Standing Orders 33 to 35 come under the general heading of "Order". S.O. 35 (9) says this:

    `Nothing in this Order shall be taken to deprive the House of the power of proceeding against any Member resolution of the House.'.

Word by word the same as S.O. 56 (5) of Singapore Standing Orders.

    Jamaica - Standing Order 29. The heading is "Speaker to be heard in silence." Standing Order 30 - "Responsibility for Order." Standing Order 31 - "Breaches of Order". I quote the equivalent of our S.O. 56 (5). That is Standing Order 31(9):

    `Nothing in this Order shall be deemed to prevent the House from proceeding against any Member for any breach of order not specified therein or from proceeding in any other way it thinks fit in dealing with the breaches of order herein mentioned.'.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, you will see that the Jamaican equivalent of S.O. 56 (5) deals, in more detail, with what is the purpose of that particular clause.

    I shall now deal with the Standing Orders of Hong Kong. Standing Order 21 - "President to be heard in silence."; S.O. 22 - "Responsibility for Order"; S.O. 23 - "Breaches of Order". I shall reproduce the equivalent of S.O. 56 (5) in Hong Kong. Their's is Standing Order 23 (9):

    `Nothing in this Order shall be deemed to prevent the Council from proceeding against any Member for any breach of order not specified therein or from proceeding in any other way it thinks fit in dealing with the breaches of order.'.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I must beg your pardon if I am trying your patience in repeating all these Standing Orders. I now come to the Gold Coast. Standing Orders 46 to 48 come under the general heading "Rules of Order". Rule 46 - "Chair to be heard in silence"; 47 - "Decision of Chair final"; 48 - "Order in the Assembly". I shall now reproduce

Column: 825

the equivalent of our S.O. 56 (5) in the Gold Coast Standing Orders. Their's is S.O.48(8):

    `Nothing in this Order shall be deemed to prevent the Assembly from proceeding against any Member for any offence not specified herein.'.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, please remember the word "offence". "Offence" means "offence against breaches of order". Now I shall produce the Standing Orders of our closest neighbour, the Federation of Malaya. Both 1950 and 1957 are the same on this subject. Standing Order 47 concerns breaches of order. S.O. 47 (9), which is the equivalent of our S.O. 56 (5), reads as follows:

    `Nothing in this rule shall be deemed to prevent the Council from proceeding against any' Member for any breach of order not specified herein or from proceeding in any other reasonable way it thinks fit in dealing with the breaches of order herein mentioned.'.

    Now, Mr Speaker, Sir, I come to Ceylon. Standing Orders 82 to 87 come under the general heading of "Order in the House", and Standing Order 87 says:

    `Nothing in these Orders shall prevent the House from proceeding against any Member for breaches of order specified in these Orders in any other manner than the manner specified in these Orders.'.

    Mr Speaker, my last quotation will be from the Standing Orders of the Assembly of Victoria, Australia. Standing Order 141 of the Victorian Parliament is a very long one and reads as follows. (It is in one Standing Order):

    `If any Member be named by the President or reported by the Chairman of Committees for

    (a) wilfully interrupting or making a disturbance during the business of the Council or Committee of the whole Council; or

    (b) disorderly conduct or;

    (c) using objectionable words and refusing to withdraw the same or behaving offensively and refusing to make a satisfactory apology; or

    (d) wilfully and persistently refusing to conform to the Standing Orders; or

    (e) wilfully disregarding the authority of the Chair,

    such Member shall be called upon to make an explanation or apology he thinks fit and a motion may be moved forthwith, no amendment, adjournment or debate being allowed, that such Member be suspended from the service of the Council during the remainder

Column: 826
